Hi Jonurena,

I'm trying to find the 2012 code for the adaptive ES-HyperNEA=
T and will
send it to you if I succeed. I think back when we developed it w=
e didn't
release the code because I wanted to clean it up a bit beforehand =
(which
somehow never happened). However, we're still very much interested i=
n
exploring how to best combine ES-HyperNEAT with plasticity.

In the meant=
ime, if you have any ES-HyperNEAT implementation questions
please don't hes=
itate to let me know.

Best,
Sebastian

On Thu, Jun 25, 2015 at 10:17 AM, j=
onurena@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> I'm afraid I =
took a succession of wrong approaches regarding how to
> replicate the pict=
ure breeding experiment with ES-HyperNEAT.
>
> In the first approach, I ass=
umed that the CPPN evolved during evolution,
> converted into a substrate (=
a regular ANN) via ES-HyperNEAT, would have
> expressed the information nec=
essary to output the whole image by loading
> the resulting ANN with an inp=
ut; therefore, I thought I needed to have as
> the single input a bias and =
as the output an entry for each coordinate in
> the resulting image: an out=
put for x0y0, another for x1y0, etc.
>
> In my second approach, I was simpl=
y trying to evolve a CPPN that would
> produce an ANN with the same inputs =
as the CPPN in the regular NEAT picture
> breeding experiment: as inputs x,=
 y and distance from center (originally I
> also considered bias as an inpu=
t, but I dropped that quick), and as the
> outputs, each component of the H=
SB values for a pixel. I had trouble then
> wrapping my head around the coo=
rdinates in which the inputs and the outputs
> should be set, to represent =
properly how they would relate to the geometry
> of the problem. I thought =
I would have a single CPPN that produces an ANN
> that would be queried for=
 each pixel. It didn't make sense that I should
> set the input Y, for exam=
ple, in a coordinate for HyperNEAT, when the
> requested coordinates would =
be different for each pixel.
>
> In my third approach, or more accurately r=
ealization, I think that to
> properly reproduce the experiment in HyperNEA=
T, I should produce a CPPN
> from the CPPN, and not only that, but run the =
substrate evolution for each
> pixel; in that case I could set up each inpu=
t at the proper position
> depending on the pixel I needed to produce the H=
SB components for. Still, I
> suspect it's fundamentally wrong to use Hyper=
NEAT to produce a CPPN instead
> of simply an ANN, because if I need the or=
ganism to run a CPPN, I simply
> should evolve the final CPPN. And running =
the substrate evolution for each
> pixel position in each organism sounds i=
nsanely expensive. So I'm dropping
> the whole thing for now and moving on =
to reproduce other experiments on
> ES-HyperNEAT.
>
> I'm running the exper=
iments on software I developed from zero in Java.
> Plenty of implementatio=
ns in Java out there, but I wanted my own to tinker
> with it as much as I =
wanted. I put extra care in implementing ES-HyperNEAT
> based on mostly the=
 most recommended software listed in the NEAT software
> catalog and articl=
es such as the one you linked, but now I'll test more
> extensively to make=
 sure I didn't screw that up, if during the first
> approach the algorithm =
should have expressed other nodes connected from
> the bias input.
>
> I im=
plemented HyperNEAT by extending the calculations and references in
> the o=
riginal code to three dimensions, as I knew in advance that I'll be
> tryin=
g to develop AI that deals with maps with Z levels.
>
> Noted on the output=
 for the evolved CPPN in HyperNEAT needing to be signed
> (ranging from -1.=
0 to 1.0) instead of unsigned. Guessing that should be the
> case as well f=
or other outputs of that CPPN, as in extended versions that
> produce plast=
ic networks.
>
> Thank you for taking the time to answer and for the fantas=
tic work you
> guys are doing.
>
>  
>



-- 
Dr. Sebastian Risi
Assistant =
Professor
IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D10
Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 230=
0 Copenhagen, Denmark

si.com

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hi=C2=A0<span style=3D"font-size:12.8000001907349px">Jonur=
ena,</span><div><br></div><div>I'm trying to find the 2012 code for the=
 adaptive ES-HyperNEAT and will send it to you if I succeed. I think back w=
hen we developed it we didn't release the code because I wanted to clea=
n it up a bit beforehand (which somehow never happened). However, we're=
 still very much interested in exploring how to best combine ES-HyperNEAT w=
ith plasticity.</div><div><br></div><div>In the meantime, if you have any E=
S-HyperNEAT implementation questions please don't hesitate to let me kn=
ow.=C2=A0</div><div><br></div><div>Best,</div><div>Sebastian</div></div><di=
v class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Thu, Jun 25, 2015=
 at 10:17 AM, <a href=3D"mailto:jonurena@...">jonurena@...</a> [n=
eat] <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com" target=
=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=
=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padd=
ing-left:1ex">


<u></u>









 
<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<=
span>=C2=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>I&#39=
;m afraid I took a succession of wrong approaches regarding how to replicat=
e the picture breeding experiment with ES-HyperNEAT.</p><div><br></div><div=
>In the first approach, I assumed that the CPPN evolved during evolution, c=
onverted into a substrate (a regular ANN) via ES-HyperNEAT, would have expr=
essed the information necessary to output the whole image by loading the re=
sulting ANN with an input; therefore, I thought I needed to have as the sin=
gle input a bias and as the output an entry for each coordinate in the resu=
lting image: an output for x0y0, another for x1y0, etc.</div><div><br></div=
><div>In my second approach, I was simply trying to evolve a CPPN that woul=
d produce an ANN with the same inputs as the CPPN in the regular NEAT pictu=
re breeding experiment: as inputs x, y and distance from center (originally=
 I also considered bias as an input, but I dropped that quick), and as the =
outputs, each component of the HSB values for a pixel. I had trouble then w=
rapping my head around the coordinates in which the inputs and the outputs =
should be set, to represent properly how they would relate to the geometry =
of the problem. I thought I would have a single CPPN that produces an ANN t=
hat would be queried for each pixel. It didn't make sense that I should=
 set the input Y, for example, in a coordinate for HyperNEAT, when the requ=
ested coordinates would be different for each pixel.</div><div><br></div><d=
iv>In my third approach, or more accurately realization, I think that to pr=
operly reproduce the experiment in HyperNEAT, I should produce a CPPN from =
the CPPN, and not only that, but run the substrate evolution for each pixel=
; in that case I could set up each input at the proper position depending o=
n the pixel I needed to produce the HSB components for. Still, I suspect it=
's fundamentally wrong to use HyperNEAT to produce a CPPN instead of si=
mply an ANN, because if I need the organism to run a CPPN, I simply should =
evolve the final CPPN. And running the substrate evolution for each pixel p=
osition in each organism sounds insanely expensive. So I'm dropping the=
 whole thing for now and moving on to reproduce other experiments on ES-Hyp=
erNEAT.</div><div><br></div><div>I'm running the experiments on softwar=
e I developed from zero in Java. Plenty of implementations in Java out ther=
e, but I wanted my own to tinker with it as much as I wanted. I put extra c=
are in implementing ES-HyperNEAT based on mostly the most recommended softw=
are listed in the NEAT software catalog and articles such as the one you li=
nked, but now I'll test more extensively to make sure I didn't scre=
w that up, if during the first approach the algorithm should have expressed=
 <span style=3D"color:rgb(63,63,63);word-spacing:normal">other nodes connec=
ted from the bias input.</span></div><div><span style=3D"color:rgb(63,63,63=
);word-spacing:normal"><br></span></div><div><span style=3D"color:rgb(63,63=
,63);word-spacing:normal">I implemented HyperNEAT by extending the calculat=
ions and references in the original code to three dimensions, as I knew in =
advance that I'll be trying to develop AI that deals with maps with Z l=
evels.</span></div><div><br></div><div>Noted on the output for the evolved =
CPPN in HyperNEAT needing to be signed (ranging from -1.0 to 1.0) instead o=
f unsigned. Guessing that should be the case as well for other outputs of t=
hat CPPN, as in extended versions that produce plastic networks.</div><div>=
<br></div><div>Thank you for taking the time to answer and for the fantasti=
c work you guys are doing.</div><p></p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div st=
yle=3D"color:#fff;min-height:0"></div>


</div>
